docs.lead_paragraph: Many women who want to lose weight turn first to machines like the Stairmaster or the treadmill, while regarding strength training as a matter of toning muscles, building strength and staving off osteoporosis. But a new study suggests that if the goal is weight loss, resistance training using weights should also play an important role.
docs.abstract: New study suggests that women should combine resistance training using weights with aerobic exercise if they want to lose weight; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Through his research on quality assessment in medicine, Dr. Avedis Donabedian of the University of Michigan became internationally known for his emphasis on the way the health care system functioned and how it might be improved. In 1972, he began his own odyssey through the health care system -- as a patient. Dr. Donabedian discussed his experiences last year in an interview with Dr. Fitzhugh Mullan, a contributing editor for the journal Health Affairs. The interview appeared in the journal this year. Dr. Donabedian died on Nov. 9 at age 81.

headline.main: An Expert on Health Care Evaluates His Own Case

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Avedis Donabedian, internationally known specialist on quality assessment in medicine, on his own odyssey through health care system as patient dealing with prostate cancer; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study calls into question the wisdom of routinely encouraging frail, elderly women to undergo mammograms. For women in their 70's and 80's who are in generally poor health, the breast screening test offers little benefit and, if it is positive for cancer, may pave the way for needless physical and psychological stress, researchers from the San Francisco Veterans Affairs Medical Center say.
docs.abstract: New study calls into question wisdom of routinely encouraging frail, elderly women to undergo mammograms; for women in their 70's and 80's who are in generally poor health, breast screening test offers little benefit (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Devices and Desires: A History of Contraceptives in America,'' by Andrea Tone, Hill and Wang, $30. In 1992, Dr. Andrea Tone was finishing her dissertation at Emory University in Atlanta and volunteering at the Feminist Women's Health Center. While her academic labors focused on the history of industry, her work at the clinic provided an entirely different kind of food for thought, and eventually for research.

headline.main: Birth Control, From 'Womb Veils' to Lysol

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Gilbert Omenn, chief executive of the University of Michigan Health System, wrote this assessment of Dr. Donabedian's views: Dr. Avedis Donabedian spent a lifetime at this university studying the system aspects of health care. As in his scholarly work, he provides a wealth of constructive criticism we must all heed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Smokers who need spinal-fusion surgery in their necks may be in for an unfortunate surprise: their habit, already associated with other health problems, may also make the surgery less successful, a new study reports. Researchers, writing in a recent Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery, said smokers healed to a lesser degree and also needed more pain medicine. There may be a hidden benefit, however, for smokers who need that extra nudge to quit. While much of tobacco's damage takes a long time to heal, reducing the risk for fusion patients may be as simple as giving up smoking before the operation.
docs.abstract: Researchers find that nicotine can retard healing of bone after surgery (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carbon monoxide gas is best known as the silent killer that seeps odorless into homes or cars when there are venting problems with an engine or burner. But researchers at Columbia have found that the same properties that make the gas so deadly may give it the potential to help save the lives of people who have heart attacks or strokes. It is possible, they said, that inhaling small amounts of the gas may help them recover.

headline.main: Carbon Monoxide Isn't Always a Killer

docs.abstract: Researchers find that same properties that make carbon monoxide gas so deadly may give it potential to help save lives of people who have heart attacks or stroke (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Experts dispute the merits of putting price tags on human organs. Under one plan, heirs of the donors would be offered tax credits against their inheritances. Gale Scott interviewed two people involved with the issue, and the following are edited excerpts of those interviews. NO. Even if financial incentives were what people were looking for in deciding whether to be organ donors -- which I doubt -- a tax incentive would create problems.

headline.main: Putting a Price on Organ Donations

docs.lead_paragraph: No one is sure why, but diabetics appear to be twice as likely to suffer from depression as those without the disease, and the incidence is even higher in women, a new study shows. Writing in this month's Diabetes Care, researchers from the Washington University School of Medicine and the Department of Veterans Affairs in St. Louis said they reached that conclusion after analyzing 25 years of data.
docs.abstract: Study suggests that depression can lead to diabetes just as diabetes can lead to depression (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: My sister had yellowish skin and a yellow cast to the whites of her eyes. She was feverish and listless and wouldn't eat. She ended up in a hospital, where the diagnosis was hepatitis. But the hospital turned out to be a long way away. Before she could get there she had a hazing to endure -- a trauma of the kind inflicted by parents who disagree on how sickness is healed.

headline.main: The Residue Of Faith And Fury

docs.abstract: Savannah Waring Walker discusses tensions over illness that her family experienced because her father believed in efficacy of medicine while her mother, a Christian Scientist, believed in prayer (M)
